assets.asset: Facing the Tangula range, a bridge, part of the Qinghai Tibet railway, crosses the upper reaches of the Yangtze river. The Beijing to Lhassa Railway, a masterpiece of engineering, completed at high cost in 2007, has been criticized for being a threat to Tibetan culture, while the Chinese governement asserts it is a major contributor to Tibet economic devlopment..

A high voltage electric pole recently installed along the Tibetan highway linking Chengdu with Lhassa. The government has heavily invested to improve infrstructures in this remote Tibetan region of Sichuan province.
Yaks heading down the mountain next to a stupa, at sunset, In Tagong (Sichuan).
In Chumarleh (Qinghai) nomads playing pool and and riding their motobikes.
A young Tibetan nomad playing pool, in Tagong (Sichuan).
In Tagong (Sichuan), a beggar sleeping on the street in spite of sub freezing temperatures. The policy of forceful resettlment of nomads, has left many without any source of income.

In Zhidoi (Qinghai) nomads playing dice below the giant statue of a Yak.Over the past decade, the nomadic lifestyle, pillar of the Tibetan culture, has changed drastically. Resettlement, the trade of horses for motobikes, urbanisation, and the mistrust of authorities for this population difficult to control, is putting their lifestyle under threat.

In Litang (Sichuan) a young nomad is showing his skills at horse riding. Litang is famous for its yearly horse festivals. Over the past years, the festival has been marred by fights between the locals and the police. In 2008, the festival was canceled.
Nomads with a monk waiting for a ride by the road near Litang (Sichuan).

A Tibetan buddhist pilgrim crawling on the asphalt road in Amdo grassland. This pilgrim has left his hometown in Gansu 6 months before and should reach Lhassa in two years. This Tibetan custom is supposed to heighten one's karma.

In Aba, buddhist monks are crossing a bridge on their way to celebrate Sojong (confession) festival at Kirti monastery. On March 16th 2008, riots in Aba have been violently supressed making many deaths among local Tibetans. Since then a military post has been set up in front of the monaatery, as well as surveillance cameras and the festival is taking place under the watchful eyes of plaincloth policemen.
The shade of worshipers walking around a Temple at Kirti Monastery during Sojong (confession) festival.

A young monk throwing payer papers in the air during Sojong festival at Kirti Monastery. Since the March 16th riots, surveillance camera have been set up around the monastery, monks have to attend reeducation classes.

In Labrang monastery (Gansu) hundreds of monks have gathered for a philosophy class while above a pilgrim is crawling around the Monastery, a common practice supposed to heighten one's Karma. Labrang was the siege of pro-Tibet independance demonstration last March. Since then the local government has tightened surveillance of the monastery, arresting monks holding political material and images of the Dalai-lama as well as imposing re-education classes.
In Labrang monastery (Gansu) hundreds of monks have gathered for a philosophy class.
In Aba, at Kirti monastery young monks have gathered to celebrate Sojong (confession) festival.
In Labrang monastery (Gansu)a pilgrim is praying in front of hundreds of monks who have gathered for a philosophy class.

In Labrang monastery (Gansu) two monks at a restaurant overlooking the Monastery. Since March 2008 pro-independence demonstrations, the government has tightened surveillance of the monastery. Reeducation classes are now imposed on the monks. The government also has many informers within the monastery, which has created a climate of mutual suscpicion among the monks.

In Litang (Sichuan) Tibetan look on as a convoy of Chinese soliders parade. Litang was one of the first city in Tibet to rise against the People's Liberation Army in 1959. Its Monastery was bombarded and scores of monks were killed.

On the street of Aba, a propaganda poster warns the locals against demonstrationtating and rioting. On March 16th 2008, locals Tibetans put fire to a police station and sacked a store owned by a Han migrant. The police shot at the demonstrators and killed many of them.

In Xiahe, a monk from Labrang monastery is surfing the web in an internet cafe. The internet is a key communication tools for Tibetans to access information and disseminate information. However, in China internet communication are monitored and number of website, including those supporting the Tibetan independance movement and the Dalai Lama, are blocked.

In Markam (Sichuan), Lobsang Ishi an 80 years old monk stands at the doors of his monastery on which propaganda posters have recently been put up. On the left side Mao-tse-tung, Deng Xiaoping and Jiang Zemin. Since the March 2008 riots in Tibet, the Chinese government has embarked on a campaign of reeducation aiming at putting back the Buddhist monasteries under control.

In a studio photo, in Yushu (Qinghai), a Tibetan nun posing in front of a picture of the Potala. She has never been there but, as many Tibetan, dreams of doing a pilgrimage to this sacred place, now a tourist attraction.
A Tibetan nomad having his picture taken in a photo studio in Yushu (Qinghai).
